item.title: bak Try this Challenge-Meditation & Prayer
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
Although practicing self-awareness activities for development can be done at any time, the best times to practice self awareness development activities are early in the morning before twilight, soon after waking up, in the evening just before the twilight and before sleeping whilst laying in bed.

  1. To practice this self-awareness activity, sit or laydown in a quiet place (it can be anywhere, even in a park or a bathroom).
  2. Consider your posture, get comfortable and close your eyelids.
  3. Spend a few minutes to get your breathing into a rhythm then gradually go through the following meditation and prayer practice.

Refreshed Breathing: Physical-Qigong Breathing: Breathe from Your Belly, Breathe Smoothly and Deeply, Exhale Fully, Never Hold Your Breath, Keep the Tip of Your Tongue on the Roof of Your Mouth, Only Breathe to 70% of Your Capacity, How to Practice Breathing.

Aligned Flow: Etheric Emotion-Balanced Emotions: Identify an intense moment, understand it, recall emotions, isolate the energy, calm the energy, release the energy, relax all emotions.

Eight Flex Resolves: Mental -Resolving blockages: Clear the mind of all thoughts, Focus on the devotion, Identify the source of the devotion, derive meaning from the words, meditate on the devotion, Avoid drifting, Stay open minded.

Eternal Pulsation: Psychic –Being at peace: Relatedness, conforming, caring, understanding without reason, nature, environments, awareness.

Spiral Expansion: Casual Karmic –Expanding self-awareness: Self-Awareness, Vibrations, Immediate awareness, External awareness, Local awareness, Channelled awareness, Enhanced Awareness.

Channelled Aspirations: Individuality Essence -Channelling chi in the body: Focus on meditations, Identify an aspiration, Implication of the meditation on the aspiration, Amend the aspirations, Identify the parts of the aspirations in occurrence, Channel all energy to the next aspiration activity, Simulate the aspiration.

Tantien Harmony: Patience – Synchronizing Tantiens: lower tantien meditation source projections, synchronizing lower and middle tantiens, middle tantien aspired projections, synchronizing middle and upper tantiens, upper tantien Real-Time Projections, experience a relaxed state of self-awareness, project the application of the aspiration.

The Eight Virtues: Unity –The Eight Virtues: Filial Piety (Reverence and loving care of our parents – teachers – elders) -Sibling Harmony (To live at peace as brothers and sisters Respectful of others) – Dedication (Loyalty – Faithfulness – Commitment), Trustworthiness (Sincerity – Honesty – Keeping one’s promises), Propriety (Courtesy – Politeness – Decorum – Manners), Sacrifi ce (Courage to do what is right – Purity of heart and purpose – Selflessness), Honour (Integrity – Incorruptible – Taking only what you deserve, having earned it), Sense of Shame (Conscientious – Cognizant of shameful action and avoiding it).

item.title: About Blue Crown Academy
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
The Academy is both an honorary society that recognizes and celebrates the excellence of its members and an independent research center convening leaders from across disciplines, professions, and perspectives to address significant challenges.

Mission

Blue Crown Academy honors excellence and convenes leaders from every field of human endeavor to examine new ideas, address global issues and work together “to cultivate every elective that may tend to advance the interest, honor, dignity, and happiness of a free, independent, and virtuous culture.”

Values

The Academy is guided by its commitment to the following values:
* Advancing the common good
* Upholding democratic ideals
* Elevating the use of evidence and knowledge
* Fostering deliberative discourse
* Preserving independence
* Embracing diversity and inclusivity
* Celebrating excellence

The Academy’s elected members join with other experts in cross-disciplinary efforts to produce reflective, independent, and pragmatic studies that inform public policy and advance the public good.

item.content:encoded:
• Access to a device with stable internet availability for streaming videos and online classes

  • P.O. Box address to receive your registration and course packages

  • Details of the last educational institution enrolled

  • Completed Koware Lifestyle profile

  • A legible scanned copy of your ID required to process the qualification

  • A legible scanned copy of your health insurance or recent health check letter from a doctor required to release the qualification

item.title: Website Address Setup
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
Wordpress Blog Setup Guide as at January 2023

    • Click to open this link https://wordpress.com/refer-a-friend/3WqPP0Gfkz9WPYpJwQ6X

    • Press on ‘Start your website’, ‘Signup to claim your credits’, 'Start Blogging' or ‘Get Started’.

    • Create your account with email, username and password if requested

    • Step 1. Type the full name for the site you would like: 

      • for example:

        testblog8475.art.blog

        • testblog8475 being your blog site’s name. You may choose from any of the free domain names below instead of art.blog

        • For example, your site address can be testblog8475.home.blog or testblog8475.photo.blog

        • You may type in any of the following free domain names:

      • art.blog

      • business.blog

      • car.blog

      • code.blog

      • data.blog

      • design.blog

      • family.blog

      • fashion.blog

      • finance.blog

      • fitness.blog

      • food.blog

      • game.blog

      • health.blog

      • home.blog

      • law.blog

      • movie.blog

      • music.blog

      • news.blog

      • photo.blog

      • poetry.blog

      • politics.blog

      • school.blog

      • science.blog

      • sport.blog

      • tech.blog

      • travel.blog

      • video.blog

      • water.blog
      ref: Announcing Free .blog Subdomains
      https://wordpress.com/blog/2018/11/28/announcing-free-dotblog-subdomains/


        • Step 2. Select a plan for your site. If you would like the free plan, select the free option near to top or near to thee bottom of the page, above or below the selection of plans.

This guide will help to set up your blog or website with Wordpress.com

item.title: Club Groups & Leisure
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
The academy hosts a variety of club groups and leisure activities. Members with an active Silver Lifestyle subscription can create clubs, groups and forums including making other posts such as articles, audio podcasts and events. All club groups and forums must abide with the Koware bylaws to avoid suspension or being removed. The creators of club groups and forums are responsible for the conduct of their members. Creators can be banned from the academy for misconduct.

The academy also hosts games and other activities that may reward members with prizes such as the Buzzjuice Raffle. The raffle is held once a term, at the end of the term, and winners are credited with Palmier Points. Members gain raffle entries through their activities with Koware online and offline. The offline entries can be issued at Koware meetups or through lucky service cards. The more entries a user has can increase the chances of winning but does not guarantee winning. The raffle is a random draw.

Feel free to join any club group and participate in any leisure activities that would be published during the terms.

item.title: Courses & Electives
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
There number of professions in the contemporary world today are increasing as new courses and discoveries are developed and distributed through institutions. Did you know there are Professional Sleepers who are paid to sleep (ref: https://ca.indeed.com/Professional-sleeper-jobs/ ). An online search for 'types of professions' would yield a multitude of results, all requiring qualifications obtained from course sitting, certificates and experience. It is never too late to start a new career; read about KFC's founder Colonel Harland Sanders.

In this topic we are going to do some research on a few of the assorted types of professions out there and their associated qualifications. Here is a list of current sites that readily provide a healthy and up to date list of professions and their associated certified courses:

  • IIE Passport
  • My Majors
  • Career Planner
  • Career Profiles

There are many more sites providing data on courses and profession that you can research on in your own time.

Opt to take an online career test to find out your best fit. According to Careerizma, it would be a good idea to take the following steps before taking any online career assessment.

Steps to matching with a career

  • Evaluate yourself
    • Personality
    • Interests
    • Favorite Subjects
    • Skills
    • Education
    • Target Lifestyle
  • List down the possible careers
  • Choose your career

More details on these steps can be found on the Careerizma site.

The following sites can be used for career assessment tests:

  • Your Free Career Test
  • Career Addict

There are more sites to take career tests on. It would be good to take as many tests as you can to identify the best career for you. Make a list of the suggested careers from each test and see what career pops up the most. Compare the results with your initial career choice in the last step to come to a conclusion on the best career for you.

For this assignment,

  • Choose any one profession of your choice and create a list of about 20 questions to interview an individual in that field. The interviews can be conducted in person, on a call, online meeting, through email or postal surveys. However may be convenient for you.
  • Write a report on the profession addressing the responses of the professional interviewed.
  • The report should be typed, doubled spaced, size 14pt text and no more than 2 pages. The 2 page report must be submitted with the 1 page questionnaire making 3 pages submitted in total. Name and date must be in the header. A cover page is not required.

*Please note that this assignment is not due immediately and is not required to complete or pass this registration & orientation. The assignment, however, must be completed and submitted to the academy by the end of any course taken with the academy. This must be done before any certificates can be issued.

item.title: Academy Bylaws
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
The Academy's bylaws are based on the Koware bylaws that can be viewed at this link URL: https://127.0.0.1/buzzjuice.net/academy/forum/bylaws/

The bylaws include the following sections:

  • Terms
  • Conditions
  • Rules
  • Regulations
  • Privacy
  • Policies
  • Procedures
  • Torah Bylaws

These bylaws are in a discussion forum format to enable the development of the bylaws by the members. Amendments to any part of the bylaws, except for the Torah Bylaws, are voted on and approved by the governing board of the academy and Koware. The Torah Bylaws are for reference and study purposes only. We encourage members to view the bylaws periodically and make their contributions to develop them. All clubs and groups are subject to these bylaws.

item.title: Institutional Collaboration
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded: To support the tangible services that members of the academy may require for the online courses, such as library services, internet access, study areas and examination facilitation, the academy requires members to identify with the nearest educational institution to them. The institution selected must have the potential to provide you with study support through the duration of your registration with Blue Crown Academy.

item.title: Developing Self Awareness
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
As you develop self awareness you are able to make changes in the thoughts and interpretations you make in your mind. Changing the interpretations in your mind allows you to change your emotions. Self awareness is developed through practices in focusing your attention on the details of your personality and behavior. Think of learning to be mindful and self aware as learning to dance. When learning to dance we have to pay attention to how and where our feet move, our hands and body motion, what our partner is doing, music, beat, floor space, and other dancers. Dancing isn’t learned from books and Self Awareness isn’t either. A dancer needs awareness of their body movements. Self awareness is what you develop when you pay attention to your expressions of thought, emotions, and behavior.

If you have an emotional reaction of anger or frustration, you notice many of the thoughts and small triggers that build up towards those emotions. You also notice moments when you can change the interpretations in your mind, or not believe what you are thinking. In this heightened awareness you instinctively make better choices in your thought process long before an emotional reaction or destructive behavior. Making changes in your behavior is much easier to do when you catch them early in the dynamic, before the momentum of thought and emotion has gathered steam. The changes in your mind and behavior become simple and easy steps when you develop self awareness. To increase your awareness the first step is to practice Becoming the Observer.

item.title: Self-Awareness & Effectiveness
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
Self-awareness helps managers identify gaps in their management skills, which promotes skill development.  But self-awareness also helps managers find situations in which they will be most effective, assists with intuitive decision making, and aids stress management and motivation of oneself and others.

  • Skill development:        

          Improvement projects should normally begin with an assessment of the gap between the current situation and the desired future situation.  Having an accurate sense of who you are helps you decide what you should do to improve.  Often, self-awareness will reveal a skills gap that you want to work on. 

  • Knowing your strengths and weaknesses:     

          Self-awareness helps you exploit your strengths and cope with your weaknesses.  For instance, if you are someone who is good at "seeing the big picture" that surrounds decisions, but not as good at focusing on the details, you might want to consult colleagues and subordinates that are more detail-oriented when making major decisions.  Cooperation between big-picture-oriented decision makers and detail-oriented decision makers can produce high quality decisions.

  • Developing intuitive decision-making skills:

           Leaders with well-developed emotional self-awareness are more effective intuitive decision makers.  In complex situations, intuitive decision makers process large amounts of sometimes unstructured and ambiguous data, and they choose a course of action based on a "gut feeling" or a "sense" of what's best.  This type of decision making is becoming more important for managers as the rate of change and the levels of uncertainty and complexity in their competitive environments increase.  Managers who are highly emotionally self-aware are better able to read their "gut feelings" and use them to guide decisions.

  • Stress:

          Jobs that don't suit your personality tend to give you more stress than jobs that are more compatible.  This is not to say that you should never take a job that conflicts with your personality.  However, be aware that you will need to work extra hard to develop the skills for that job, and there are jobs that would be less stressful for you. 

  • Motivation:

          It's very difficult to cope with poor results when you don't understand what causes them.  When you don't know what behaviours to change to improve your performance, you just feel helpless.  Self-awareness is empowering because it can reveal where the performance problems are and indicate what can be done to improve performance.  In addition, awareness of your psychological needs can increase your motivation by helping you understand and seek out the rewards that you really desire such as a sense of accomplishment, additional responsibility, an opportunity to help others, or a flexible work schedule.

  • Leadership:

          When we understand "what make us tick"--what gets us excited, why we behave the way we do, etc.--we also have insight into what makes others tick.  To the extent that other people are like you (and, of course, there are limits to the similarity), knowing how to motivate yourself is tantamount to knowing how to motivate others.

item.title: Key Areas for Self-Awareness
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
Human beings are complex and diverse.  To become more self-aware, we should develop an understanding of ourselves in many areas.  Key areas for self-awareness include our personality traits, personal values, habits, emotions, and the psychological needs that drive our behaviors.

  • Personality:

We don't normally change our personalities, values and needs based on what we learn about ourselves.  But, an understanding of our personalities can help us find situations in which we will thrive, and help us avoid situations in which we will experience too much stress.  For instance, if you are a highly introverted person, you are likely to experience more stress in a sales position than a highly extroverted person would.  So, if you are highly introverted, you should either learn skills to cope with the demands of a sales position that requires extravert-type behaviour patterns, or you should find a position that is more compatible with your personality.  Awareness of your personality helps you analyze such a decision. 
        Roy Disney and Stanley Gold would say that Michael Eisner's personality is too controlling.  He has buffered himself from threats to his tenure as CEO by co-opting the board of directors and by micro-managing the executives he should be developing and empowering.  As a result, his performance as CEO has suffered.

  • Values:

It's important that we each know and focus on our personal values.  For instance, if your first priority is "being there for your children" or "your relationship with God," it's very easy to lose sight of those priorities on a day-to-day, moment-by-moment basis.  During the workday, so many problems and opportunities arise that our lists of "things to do" can easily exceed the time we have to do them.  Since few (if any) of those things pertain to what we value most, it's easy to spend too much time on lower priority activities.  When we focus on our values, we are more likely to accomplish what we consider most important.

  • Habits:

Our habits are the behaviours that we repeat routinely and often automatically.  Although we would like to possess the habits that help us interact effectively with and manage others, we can probably all identify at least one of our habits that decreases our effectiveness.  For example, if you are a manager who never consults your staff before making decisions, that habit may interfere with your ability to build your staff members' commitment to the decisions and their decision-making skills as well.

  • Needs:

Maslow and other scholars have identified a variety of psychological needs that drive our behaviours such as needs for esteem, affection, belongingness, achievement, self-actualization, power and control.  One of the advantages of knowing which needs exert the strongest influence on our own behaviours is the ability to understand how they affect our interpersonal relationships.  For instance, most of us have probably known people who have a high need for status.  They're attracted to high status occupations, and they seek high status positions within their organizations.  Such people also want the things that symbolize their status.  They insist that they be shown respect, and they want privileges and perks that people of lower status can't have.  Sometimes these people fight for things that others see as inconsequential--like a bigger office.  Needs cause motivation; and when needs aren't satisfied, they can cause frustration, conflict and stress.

  • Emotions:

Emotional self-awareness has become a hot topic of discussion recently because it's one of the five facets of emotional intelligence.  Understanding your own feelings, what causes them, and how they impact your thoughts and actions is emotional self-awareness.  If you were once excited about your job but not excited now, can you get excited again?  To answer that question, it helps to understand the internal processes associated with getting excited.  That sounds simpler than it is.  Here's an analogy: I think I know how my car starts--I put gas in the tank, put the key in the ignition, and turn the key.  But, my mechanic knows a lot more about what's involved in getting my car started than I do--he knows what happens under the hood.  My mechanic is able to start my car on the occasions when I'm not because he understands the internal processes.  Similarly, a person with high emotional self-awareness understands the internal process associated with emotional experiences and, therefore, has greater control over them.

item.title: The Johari Window
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
The Johari Window can be looked at from many angles and provides four basic forms of the Self (the Known, Hidden, Blind, and Unknown Self).

The Known Self is what you and others see in you. This is the part that you are able to discuss freely with others. Most of the time you agree with this view you have and others have of you.

The Hidden Self is what you see in yourself but others don’t. In this part you hide things that are very private about yourself. You do not want this information to be disclosed for the reason of protection. It could also be that you may be ashamed of these areas and feel a vulnerability to having your faults and weaknesses exposed. This area equally applies to your good qualities that you don’t want to advertise to the world due to modesty.

The Blind Self is what you don’t see in yourself but others see in you. You might see yourself as an open-minded person when, in reality, people around you don’t agree. This area also works the other way. You might see yourself as a “dumb” person while others might consider you incredibly bright. Sometimes those around you might not tell you what they see because they fear offending you. It is in this area that people sometimes detect that what you say and what you do don’t match and sometimes body-language shows this mismatch.

The Unknown Self is the self that you cannot see, others can’t see it either. In this category there might be good and bad things that are out of the awareness of others and you. This might refer to untapped potential talents and skills that have yet to be explored by you, your friends, colleagues or managers.

You may find the Johari Window quite useful as you discover who you are.

item.title: Types of Self-Awareness
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
Psychologists often break self-awareness down into two different types, either public or private.

Public Self-Awareness:

            This type emerges when people are aware of how they appear to others. Public self-awareness often emerges in situations where people are at the center of attention, such as when giving a presentation or talking to a group of friends. This type of self-awareness often compels people to adhere to social norms. When we are aware that we are being watched and evaluated, we often try to behave in ways that are socially acceptable and desirable. Public self-awareness can also lead to evaluation anxiety in which people become distressed, anxious, or worried about how they are perceived by others. People who are publicly self-conscious have a higher level of public self-awareness. They tend to think more about how other people view them and are often concerned that other people might be judging them based on their looks or their actions. As a result, these individuals tend to stick to group norms and try to avoid situations in which they might look bad or feel embarrassed.

Private Self-Awareness:

            This type happens when people become aware of some aspects of themselves, but only in a private way. For example, seeing your face in the mirror is a type of private self-awareness. Feeling your stomach lurch when you realize you forgot to study for an important test or feeling your heart flutter when you see someone you are attracted to are also good examples of private self-awareness. People who are privately self-conscious have a higher level of private self-awareness, which can be both a good and bad thing. These people tend to be more aware of their feelings and beliefs, and are therefore more likely to stick to their personal values. However, they are also more likely to suffer from negative health consequences such as increased stress and anxiety.

Self-Consciousness; A Heightened State of Self-Awareness:

            Sometimes, people can become overly self-aware and veer into what is known as self-consciousness. Have you ever felt like everyone was watching you, judging your actions, and waiting to see what you will do next? This heightened state of self-awareness can leave you feeling awkward and nervous in some instances. In a lot of cases, these feelings of self-consciousness are only temporary and arise in situations when we are "in the spotlight." For some people, however, self-consciousness can become a chronic condition.

With practice we can learn to engage heightened states of awareness and see new opportunities for interpretations in our thoughts, emotions, and conversations.

item.title: Try this Challenge-Meditation & Prayer
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
Although practicing self-awareness activities for development can be done at any time, the best times to practice self awareness development activities are early in the morning before twilight, soon after waking up, in the evening just before the twilight and before sleeping whilst laying in bed.

  1. To practice this self-awareness activity, sit or laydown in a quiet place (it can be anywhere, even in a park or a bathroom).
  2. Consider your posture, get comfortable and close your eyelids.
  3. Spend a few minutes to get your breathing into a rhythm then gradually go through the following meditation and prayer practice.

Refreshed Breathing: Physical-Qigong Breathing: Breathe from Your Belly, Breathe Smoothly and Deeply, Exhale Fully, Never Hold Your Breath, Keep the Tip of Your Tongue on the Roof of Your Mouth, Only Breathe to 70% of Your Capacity, How to Practice Breathing.

Aligned Flow: Etheric Emotion-Balanced Emotions: Identify an intense moment, understand it, recall emotions, isolate the energy, calm the energy, release the energy, relax all emotions.

Eight Flex Resolves: Mental -Resolving blockages: Clear the mind of all thoughts, Focus on the devotion, Identify the source of the devotion, derive meaning from the words, meditate on the devotion, Avoid drifting, Stay open minded.

Eternal Pulsation: Psychic –Being at peace: Relatedness, conforming, caring, understanding without reason, nature, environments, awareness.

Spiral Expansion: Casual Karmic –Expanding self-awareness: Self-Awareness, Vibrations, Immediate awareness, External awareness, Local awareness, Channelled awareness, Enhanced Awareness.

Channelled Aspirations: Individuality Essence -Channelling chi in the body: Focus on meditations, Identify an aspiration, Implication of the meditation on the aspiration, Amend the aspirations, Identify the parts of the aspirations in occurrence, Channel all energy to the next aspiration activity, Simulate the aspiration.

Tantien Harmony: Patience – Synchronizing Tantiens: lower tantien meditation source projections, synchronizing lower and middle tantiens, middle tantien aspired projections, synchronizing middle and upper tantiens, upper tantien Real-Time Projections, experience a relaxed state of self-awareness, project the application of the aspiration.

The Eight Virtues: Unity –The Eight Virtues: Filial Piety (Reverence and loving care of our parents – teachers – elders) -Sibling Harmony (To live at peace as brothers and sisters Respectful of others) – Dedication (Loyalty – Faithfulness – Commitment), Trustworthiness (Sincerity – Honesty – Keeping one’s promises), Propriety (Courtesy – Politeness – Decorum – Manners), Sacrifi ce (Courage to do what is right – Purity of heart and purpose – Selflessness), Honour (Integrity – Incorruptible – Taking only what you deserve, having earned it), Sense of Shame (Conscientious – Cognizant of shameful action and avoiding it).

item.title: Managing Self-Awareness
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
You can become more self-aware by seeking feedback from people who know you, completing self-assessment surveys, and hiring an expert like a professional counsellor or executive coach. 

  • Ask somebody:

          If you have open, trusting relationships with the people who know you, you can ask them for feedback about your personality, habits, needs and values.  Research shows that your co-workers, friends and family members CAN provide valid assessments of your personality.  But, they do NOT ALWAYS provide an accurate assessment.  For instance, I once asked my undergraduate students to describe my personality on the four Myers-Briggs personality dimensions, and they described the exact opposite of my actual personality.  Their ratings described the personality that is appropriate for a teacher, and they also rated me as an effective teacher.  So, they saw me act like a teacher in my role as a teacher, but those behaviors are not representative of my behaviors in other roles.  There are two lessons in that:  (1) You can develop skills for a role that doesn't match your personality.  (2) People who only see you in one role can only describe your behaviors in relation to that role.  Analogously, if you mismanage your time so that you spend too much time on things that don't matter much to you, people will have a very different perception of your values than you do.  For instance, maybe you say that your family is important to you, but how do you spend your time? 
        Another limitation on the value of the feedback you get from family, friends and especially coworkers is that they may not be completely candid with you.  This is where the trust factor looms large.  Unflattering feedback is the type that has the most potential for helping you develop your management skills, but it is also the most difficult to give and to accept.  People aren't very likely to give you unflattering feedback if there isn't a high level of trust in your relationship with them ... unless they don't mind harming the relationship.  For this reason, many experts (e.g., Ed Eppley, Area Manager for Dale Carnegie Training, and Ellen Van Velsor of theCenter for Creative Leadership) suggest that managers find a way to get anonymous feedback from staff members and co-workers. 

  • Questionnaires:

          One of the ways to improve the quality of the feedback that you can receive from other people is by asking them to fill out a psychometrically sound inventory of your personality, values, needs, or habits as they perceive them.  Those surveys are composed and structured in such a way as to maximize the accuracy of the feedback they generate.  With the help of a facilitator, the surveys can be completed anonymously.  You can also fill out surveys yourself as a means of self-assessment. 

  • Seek professional help:

          Professional counsellors and executive coaches can be a great source of feedback to help you develop your self-awareness.  Of course, not everyone who calls herself a coach is qualified.  You should evaluate the training and certifications of counsellors and coaches.  Nevertheless, executive coaching is a great resource, and it's a growing area of management consulting.  Coaches not only help you get a better picture of who you are; they also guide you through self-improvement.  Often coaches collect anonymous evaluations of their clients from their subordinates, superiors or anyone else who is in a position to provide helpful feedback.  Good coaches know how to effectively collect and digest the feedback.  Professional counsellors, such as guidance counsellors and clinical psychologists, are also great resources.  Guidance counsellors can provide inventories of your personality and interests.  Clinical psychologists can help you understand and work on aspects of your personality and habits that interfere with any facet of your life, including work.

item.title: Developing Self Awareness
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
As you develop self awareness you are able to make changes in the thoughts and interpretations you make in your mind. Changing the interpretations in your mind allows you to change your emotions. Self awareness is developed through practices in focusing your attention on the details of your personality and behavior. Think of learning to be mindful and self aware as learning to dance. When learning to dance we have to pay attention to how and where our feet move, our hands and body motion, what our partner is doing, music, beat, floor space, and other dancers. Dancing isn’t learned from books and Self Awareness isn’t either. A dancer needs awareness of their body movements. Self awareness is what you develop when you pay attention to your expressions of thought, emotions, and behavior.

If you have an emotional reaction of anger or frustration, you notice many of the thoughts and small triggers that build up towards those emotions. You also notice moments when you can change the interpretations in your mind, or not believe what you are thinking. In this heightened awareness you instinctively make better choices in your thought process long before an emotional reaction or destructive behavior. Making changes in your behavior is much easier to do when you catch them early in the dynamic, before the momentum of thought and emotion has gathered steam. The changes in your mind and behavior become simple and easy steps when you develop self awareness. To increase your awareness the first step is to practice Becoming the Observer.

item.title: Self-Awareness & Effectiveness
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
Self-awareness helps managers identify gaps in their management skills, which promotes skill development.  But self-awareness also helps managers find situations in which they will be most effective, assists with intuitive decision making, and aids stress management and motivation of oneself and others.

  • Skill development:        

          Improvement projects should normally begin with an assessment of the gap between the current situation and the desired future situation.  Having an accurate sense of who you are helps you decide what you should do to improve.  Often, self-awareness will reveal a skills gap that you want to work on. 

  • Knowing your strengths and weaknesses:     

          Self-awareness helps you exploit your strengths and cope with your weaknesses.  For instance, if you are someone who is good at "seeing the big picture" that surrounds decisions, but not as good at focusing on the details, you might want to consult colleagues and subordinates that are more detail-oriented when making major decisions.  Cooperation between big-picture-oriented decision makers and detail-oriented decision makers can produce high quality decisions.

  • Developing intuitive decision-making skills:

           Leaders with well-developed emotional self-awareness are more effective intuitive decision makers.  In complex situations, intuitive decision makers process large amounts of sometimes unstructured and ambiguous data, and they choose a course of action based on a "gut feeling" or a "sense" of what's best.  This type of decision making is becoming more important for managers as the rate of change and the levels of uncertainty and complexity in their competitive environments increase.  Managers who are highly emotionally self-aware are better able to read their "gut feelings" and use them to guide decisions.

  • Stress:

          Jobs that don't suit your personality tend to give you more stress than jobs that are more compatible.  This is not to say that you should never take a job that conflicts with your personality.  However, be aware that you will need to work extra hard to develop the skills for that job, and there are jobs that would be less stressful for you. 

  • Motivation:

          It's very difficult to cope with poor results when you don't understand what causes them.  When you don't know what behaviours to change to improve your performance, you just feel helpless.  Self-awareness is empowering because it can reveal where the performance problems are and indicate what can be done to improve performance.  In addition, awareness of your psychological needs can increase your motivation by helping you understand and seek out the rewards that you really desire such as a sense of accomplishment, additional responsibility, an opportunity to help others, or a flexible work schedule.

  • Leadership:

          When we understand "what make us tick"--what gets us excited, why we behave the way we do, etc.--we also have insight into what makes others tick.  To the extent that other people are like you (and, of course, there are limits to the similarity), knowing how to motivate yourself is tantamount to knowing how to motivate others.

item.title: Key Areas for Self-Awareness
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
Human beings are complex and diverse.  To become more self-aware, we should develop an understanding of ourselves in many areas.  Key areas for self-awareness include our personality traits, personal values, habits, emotions, and the psychological needs that drive our behaviors.

  • Personality:

We don't normally change our personalities, values and needs based on what we learn about ourselves.  But, an understanding of our personalities can help us find situations in which we will thrive, and help us avoid situations in which we will experience too much stress.  For instance, if you are a highly introverted person, you are likely to experience more stress in a sales position than a highly extroverted person would.  So, if you are highly introverted, you should either learn skills to cope with the demands of a sales position that requires extravert-type behaviour patterns, or you should find a position that is more compatible with your personality.  Awareness of your personality helps you analyze such a decision. 
        Roy Disney and Stanley Gold would say that Michael Eisner's personality is too controlling.  He has buffered himself from threats to his tenure as CEO by co-opting the board of directors and by micro-managing the executives he should be developing and empowering.  As a result, his performance as CEO has suffered.

  • Values:

It's important that we each know and focus on our personal values.  For instance, if your first priority is "being there for your children" or "your relationship with God," it's very easy to lose sight of those priorities on a day-to-day, moment-by-moment basis.  During the workday, so many problems and opportunities arise that our lists of "things to do" can easily exceed the time we have to do them.  Since few (if any) of those things pertain to what we value most, it's easy to spend too much time on lower priority activities.  When we focus on our values, we are more likely to accomplish what we consider most important.

  • Habits:

Our habits are the behaviours that we repeat routinely and often automatically.  Although we would like to possess the habits that help us interact effectively with and manage others, we can probably all identify at least one of our habits that decreases our effectiveness.  For example, if you are a manager who never consults your staff before making decisions, that habit may interfere with your ability to build your staff members' commitment to the decisions and their decision-making skills as well.

  • Needs:

Maslow and other scholars have identified a variety of psychological needs that drive our behaviours such as needs for esteem, affection, belongingness, achievement, self-actualization, power and control.  One of the advantages of knowing which needs exert the strongest influence on our own behaviours is the ability to understand how they affect our interpersonal relationships.  For instance, most of us have probably known people who have a high need for status.  They're attracted to high status occupations, and they seek high status positions within their organizations.  Such people also want the things that symbolize their status.  They insist that they be shown respect, and they want privileges and perks that people of lower status can't have.  Sometimes these people fight for things that others see as inconsequential--like a bigger office.  Needs cause motivation; and when needs aren't satisfied, they can cause frustration, conflict and stress.

  • Emotions:

Emotional self-awareness has become a hot topic of discussion recently because it's one of the five facets of emotional intelligence.  Understanding your own feelings, what causes them, and how they impact your thoughts and actions is emotional self-awareness.  If you were once excited about your job but not excited now, can you get excited again?  To answer that question, it helps to understand the internal processes associated with getting excited.  That sounds simpler than it is.  Here's an analogy: I think I know how my car starts--I put gas in the tank, put the key in the ignition, and turn the key.  But, my mechanic knows a lot more about what's involved in getting my car started than I do--he knows what happens under the hood.  My mechanic is able to start my car on the occasions when I'm not because he understands the internal processes.  Similarly, a person with high emotional self-awareness understands the internal process associated with emotional experiences and, therefore, has greater control over them.

item.title: The Johari Window
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
The Johari Window can be looked at from many angles and provides four basic forms of the Self (the Known, Hidden, Blind, and Unknown Self).

The Known Self is what you and others see in you. This is the part that you are able to discuss freely with others. Most of the time you agree with this view you have and others have of you.

The Hidden Self is what you see in yourself but others don’t. In this part you hide things that are very private about yourself. You do not want this information to be disclosed for the reason of protection. It could also be that you may be ashamed of these areas and feel a vulnerability to having your faults and weaknesses exposed. This area equally applies to your good qualities that you don’t want to advertise to the world due to modesty.

The Blind Self is what you don’t see in yourself but others see in you. You might see yourself as an open-minded person when, in reality, people around you don’t agree. This area also works the other way. You might see yourself as a “dumb” person while others might consider you incredibly bright. Sometimes those around you might not tell you what they see because they fear offending you. It is in this area that people sometimes detect that what you say and what you do don’t match and sometimes body-language shows this mismatch.

The Unknown Self is the self that you cannot see, others can’t see it either. In this category there might be good and bad things that are out of the awareness of others and you. This might refer to untapped potential talents and skills that have yet to be explored by you, your friends, colleagues or managers.

You may find the Johari Window quite useful as you discover who you are.

item.title: Types of Self-Awareness
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
Psychologists often break self-awareness down into two different types, either public or private.

Public Self-Awareness:

            This type emerges when people are aware of how they appear to others. Public self-awareness often emerges in situations where people are at the center of attention, such as when giving a presentation or talking to a group of friends. This type of self-awareness often compels people to adhere to social norms. When we are aware that we are being watched and evaluated, we often try to behave in ways that are socially acceptable and desirable. Public self-awareness can also lead to evaluation anxiety in which people become distressed, anxious, or worried about how they are perceived by others. People who are publicly self-conscious have a higher level of public self-awareness. They tend to think more about how other people view them and are often concerned that other people might be judging them based on their looks or their actions. As a result, these individuals tend to stick to group norms and try to avoid situations in which they might look bad or feel embarrassed.

Private Self-Awareness:

            This type happens when people become aware of some aspects of themselves, but only in a private way. For example, seeing your face in the mirror is a type of private self-awareness. Feeling your stomach lurch when you realize you forgot to study for an important test or feeling your heart flutter when you see someone you are attracted to are also good examples of private self-awareness. People who are privately self-conscious have a higher level of private self-awareness, which can be both a good and bad thing. These people tend to be more aware of their feelings and beliefs, and are therefore more likely to stick to their personal values. However, they are also more likely to suffer from negative health consequences such as increased stress and anxiety.

Self-Consciousness; A Heightened State of Self-Awareness:

            Sometimes, people can become overly self-aware and veer into what is known as self-consciousness. Have you ever felt like everyone was watching you, judging your actions, and waiting to see what you will do next? This heightened state of self-awareness can leave you feeling awkward and nervous in some instances. In a lot of cases, these feelings of self-consciousness are only temporary and arise in situations when we are "in the spotlight." For some people, however, self-consciousness can become a chronic condition.

With practice we can learn to engage heightened states of awareness and see new opportunities for interpretations in our thoughts, emotions, and conversations.

item.title: Navigating the Platform
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
• Courses Dashboard Overview:
    When you log in and access the courses page, your dashboard would display at the top of the page, displaying your enrolled courses, announcements, profile links and other course data related to your profile.
  • Courses Page:
    Access the “Courses” page via the top menu, mobile menu, bottom menu or sidebar. Here you’ll see:
    • Lessons and topics with progress indicators.
    • Course List (active and available courses).
    • Quizzes, assignments, and forums linked to each course.
  • Socials Page: {{Under Construction}}
    Match similar interests with members, Join discussion groups and forums to collaborate, ask questions, and share resources.

👉 Action Step: Explore the dashboard now. Locate the “Courses” and “Socials” menu items.

item.title: Updating Your Profile
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
Your Buzzjuice profile serves as your official registration record. Incomplete profiles may block access to certain Health & Safety and Elective course assessments.

  1. Tap here to navigate to your Profile → Edit Profile.
  2. Complete all required 'Account Info' fields:
    • Full name
    • Secondary High School, and Location
    • Nearest educational institution to you
    • Nearest or preferred medical center
  3. Tap here to upload a clear profile photo (recommended).

👉 Action Step: Tap here to update your profile now. Make sure required fields are filled before moving forward.

item.title: Course Structure & Progress
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
Each course contains:

  • Lesson Modules: main learning units with text, video, or PDFs.
  • Topics: sub-sections under lesson modules for detailed concepts.
  • Quizzes/Assignments: short tests or tasks at the end of lesson modules.
  • Completion Rules:
    • Some lessons require passing a quiz before being accessed.
    • Most final assessments require a 60% pass rate and may depend on a learning curve.

👉 Action Step: Review the lessons in this Orientation course to see how lesson modules, topics, and progress tracking work.

item.title: Finding Support
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
If you encounter problems, help is available:

  • Help & Support Email: support@buzzjuice.net
  • Community Groups: join forums to ask questions.
  • Support FAQ Forum: check common issues about subscriptions, login, or course access.
  • Buzzjuice Broadcast: stay updated on new courses, timetable changes, and bylaw updates.
  • Buzzjuice Courses Telegram Group: Extension of the Buzzjuice Broadcast for courses.

👉 Action Step: Bookmark the support email, link to Community Groups, the Support FAQ Forum, the Buzzjuice Broadcast and Telegram Group for future updates.

item.title: Welcome & Platform Tour - Lesson Summary
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
Lesson Summary

In this lesson module, you learned:

  • How to navigate the Buzzjuice Courses platform.
  • How to update your Buzzjuice profile.
  • The structure of courses and progress requirements.
  • Where to find help and support.

✅ Next Step: Mark this lesson module complete to continue to Lesson Module 2 — Subscriptions & Pricing.

item.title: Why Subscriptions Are Required
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
• All Buzzjuice Courses operate on a subscription model.
  • The subscription covers your registration fee and enables access to exclusive learning content.
  • Without an active subscription, you will not be able to:
    • Take the Registration & Orientation final assessment.
    • Access Health & Safety and Elective course quizzes or graded activities.
    • Earn certificates or badges.

👉 Key Point: An active subscription is the foundation of your registration.

item.title: Subscription Plans & Pricing
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
Buzzjuice offers four subscription options. You can choose the plan that best suits your study schedule:

  • Longer plans offer better value per month.
  • You may upgrade, downgrade, or renew your plan at any time from your Account > Subscriptions page.
  • Payments are securely processed through Paystack.com

👉 Tip: Choose a longer plan if you want uninterrupted access and lower monthly cost.

item.title: Payment Rules & Renewals
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
• Auto-renewal: By default, subscriptions should be manually renewed. You can activate auto-renewal in your account settings.
  • Failed payments: If your payment fails, your account will temporarily lose access until payment is resolved.
  • Renewal reminders: Emails will be sent 7 days and 1 day before your renewal date.
  • Cancellation: Cancelling a subscription ends access at the end of your current billing period.

👉 Important: Losing your subscription mid-course will immediately block access to Health & Safety and Elective course content until you renew.

item.title: Subscription + Orientation Rules
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
• To attempt the Registration & Orientation final quiz, you must have an active subscription.
  • Completing and passing the Registration & Orientation assessment verifies you as active and enrolled.
  • To continue into Health & Safety and Elective courses, you must:
    1. Have an active subscription, and
    2. Pass the Orientation quiz with at least 60%.

👉 Both an active subscription and completed orientation status are required for access.

item.title: Refunds & Support
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
• Refund policy: Refunds are only available if you cancel within 14 days of your first subscription payment and have not yet attempted a course quiz.
    • As payments are set by you to be manually or automatically made, any subsequent subscription payments made after your first subscription payment are non-refundable.
  • Support: For billing issues, contact:
    • Email: support@buzzjuice.net
    • Support Page: [Buzzjuice Support FAQ Portal]
  • Always include your order number in support requests.

👉 Reminder: If you experience subscription issues, contact support quickly to avoid losing course progress.

item.title: Subscriptions & Pricing - Summary
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
By now, you should understand:

  1. Why subscriptions are required.
  2. The four subscription plans and their pricing.
  3. The rules for payment, renewal, and cancellation.
  4. How subscriptions and orientation work together to unlock Health & Safety and Elective courses.
  5. Where to find refund policies and support.

✅ Next Steps

  • Tap here to review your current subscription or tap here to purchase a subscription if you haven’t already.
  • Make sure auto-renewal settings are correct in your account.
  • Prepare to test your knowledge of subscription rules in the Orientation Final Assessment.

item.title: Why Gating Exists
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
Buzzjuice Courses use gating rules to make sure that learners are properly prepared and have active subscriptions before accessing exclusive Health & Safety content.

Gating exists for three main reasons:

  1. Fair access — Only subscribers who support the platform financially can access advanced training.
  2. Quality assurance — Orientation ensures you understand the rules before starting Health & Safety courses.
  3. Integrity — Prevents users without registration or expired orientation from bypassing requirements.

Think of gating as a secure doorway: only learners with the right keys (subscription + orientation pass) can enter.

item.title: The Role of Subscriptions
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
To access any exclusive course, lesson, or quiz, you must hold an active subscription.

📌 Buzzjuice subscription plans:

  • 27 GHC per month
  • 50 GHC every 3 months
  • 82 GHC every 6 months
  • 150 GHC every 12 months

If your subscription expires:

  • You will be redirected automatically to the subscription purchase page when trying to access exclusive content.
  • You must renew to continue learning.

item.title: The Exclusive-Content Tag
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
Certain courses, lessons, and quizzes are labeled with the “exclusive-content” tag.

This means:

  • The system checks for your subscription status before loading the page.
  • If your subscription is inactive, you’ll be redirected to the subscription purchase page.
  • If your subscription is active but orientation is incomplete, you’ll be prompted to finish Orientation first.

Example:
If you try to access a Health & Safety quiz without an active subscription, you’ll be redirected to the subscription page.

item.title: Orientation and Student Status
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
Completing Orientation is just as important as holding a subscription.

  • Once you pass the Orientation final assessment, you’ll gain access to Health & Safety and Elective course content.
  • Passing the orientation is a second key, unlocking Buzzjuice Courses, including Health & Safety content alongside your subscription.
  • Without Orientation, you cannot progress into Buzzjuice Courses or the Health & Safety Diploma, even if your subscription is active.

item.title: Losing Access
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
There are two common reasons learners lose access:

  1. Subscription expires — you will be redirected to renew.
  2. Orientation expires — after 12 months, your Orientation status lapses, and all course data is deleted.

To restore access:

  • Renew your subscription (if expired).
  • Re-complete Orientation to regain Oriented status.

This ensures all learners remain up-to-date and compliant with Buzzjuice policies.

item.title: Access Rules & Gating - Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
• Access to Health & Safety courses is gated by subscription + orientation.
  • The exclusive-content tag enforces these rules automatically.
  • Orientation completion is required for further progress.
  • Losing access = renew subscription + redo Orientation (if expired).
  • Gating protects course integrity and ensures a fair learning environment.

✨ End of Lesson 3: Access Rules & Gating ✨

item.title: Orientation Expiry (12 months)
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
• Your Registration & Orientation completion is valid for 12 months from the date you pass the final assessment.
  • After 12 months, your R&O status expires, and your access to Health & Safety and Elective courses will be restricted until you renew.
  • The expiry countdown begins immediately after passing the orientation assessment, not at the point of subscription renewal.

Key Point: Expiry is tied to your orientation completion, not just your subscription.

item.title: Data Retention & Deletion
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
• Once the 12-month period ends, all course and user statistics connected to your Registration & Orientation are deleted.
  • Deleted data includes:
    • Registration & Orientation Course progress records
    • Registration & Orientation Lesson completions
    • Registration & Orientation Quiz attempts and scores
    • Registration & Orientation certificate and badge
  • This ensures compliance with platform policies and creates a fair reset for all learners.

Note: Personal details stored in your Buzzjuice profile (e.g., education history, emergency contact, health information) remain intact and are not deleted.

item.title: Renewal & Re-registration
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
To regain full access after expiry, you must:

  1. Maintain an active subscription (renew your subscription plan if expired).
  2. Re-complete the Registration & Orientation course (all lessons + final assessment).
  3. Pass the orientation quiz again to restore your “Student” status.

Only then will your access to Health & Safety courses be unlocked.

item.title: Reminder Notifications
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
• You will receive automated reminder emails before your 12-month orientation expiry.
  • Reminders are typically sent at: 30, 14, 7, 3, and 1 day(s) before expiry.
  • These notifications help you renew on time and avoid losing your course progress.

Tip: Add support@buzzjuice.net to your safe senders list so you don’t miss these reminders.

item.title: Importance of Staying Current
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
Why does Buzzjuice enforce expiry and renewal?

  • To keep learners engaged and accountable.
  • To make sure learners always know the latest platform rules and subscription policies.
  • To ensure compliance with the Health & Safety diploma structure.

This process supports a fair learning environment and strengthens the credibility of Buzzjuice certifications.

item.title: Expiry, Retention & Re-registration - Lesson Summary
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
• Orientation status is valid for 12 months.
  • After expiry, orientation course data is deleted.
  • Re-registration requires a valid subscription + retaking orientation.
  • Reminder emails help you act before your expiry date.
  • Expiry rules keep the learning community fair, current, and compliant.

✨ End of Lesson 4 — Expiry, Retention & Re-registration

item.title: What Are the Bylaws?
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
• Bylaws are the official rules that guide how members behave and interact on Buzzjuice Courses.
  • They apply to:
    • Course activities (assignments, quizzes, projects).
    • Community spaces (forums, groups, discussions).
    • Clubs, groups, and leisure activities created by members.
  • The bylaws are living documents. Except for the “Torah Bylaws” (reference only), members can propose improvements. Updates are approved by the academy governing board.

👉 Full bylaws are available in the Buzzjuice “Policies & Bylaws” forum. Members are encouraged to read and contribute.

item.title: Categories of Bylaws
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
The bylaws are organized into the following categories:

  1. Terms & Conditions – define membership rules and responsibilities.
  2. Policies & Procedures – outline how courses, subscriptions, and certificates are managed.
  3. Rules & Regulations – cover standards for conduct, cheating, and misuse of the platform.
  4. Privacy & Security – explain how your data is handled and protected.
  5. Torah Bylaws (Reference Only) – preserved for study and cannot be changed.

These categories ensure every member knows what is expected and what protections are in place.

Tap on any category to view the related bylaws.

item.title: Conduct & Community Standards
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
• Respectful Communication: Always engage politely in discussions, forums, and messages.
  • No Cheating or Misuse: Cheating in quizzes/assessments or misusing forums may result in suspension.
  • Responsibility in Clubs & Groups: Group creators are responsible for their members’ conduct. Misconduct may lead to bans.
  • Bylaw Enforcement: Repeated violations can lead to account suspension or permanent removal.

Remember: These rules are in place to protect you and the learning community.

item.title: Assessment Rules
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
• Some Health & Safety assessments must be passed before you can continue to the next lesson.
  • Passing grade requirement: Orientation = 60%. Health & Safety = course-specific (varies).
  • Retakes: Up to 3 retakes allowed, with support materials provided between attempts.
  • Academic Integrity:
    • Do your own work.
    • Use only permitted resources.
    • Sharing answers or impersonation is a violation of bylaws.
    • Following these integral rules makes your final career predictions more accurate.

👉 Violating assessment rules can result in course suspension or loss of Student status.

item.title: Where to Get Help
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
Bylaws Forum – contains the full text of bylaws and space for community discussion.

Support Team – if you’re unsure about a rule, contact support@buzzjuice.net.

Buzzjuice Broadcast Announcements Group – admins post updates if bylaws or policies change.

item.title: Academy Bylaws, Conduct & Assessment Rules - Lesson Summary
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
In this lesson, you explored:

  • The purpose of bylaws.
  • The categories of rules that apply to all members.
  • Standards of conduct in courses and community activities.
  • Assessment rules for quizzes, assignments, and exams.
  • Where to find bylaws and get help.

✅ Understanding and following these rules ensures a safe, respectful, and supportive learning environment for everyone.

👉 Next Step: Once you’ve completed this lesson, proceed to the Final Assessment lesson, where you’ll demonstrate your understanding of the subscription, conduct, and assessment rules.

item.title: Where to Get Help & Support
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
Every learner occasionally needs support. On Buzzjuice Courses, support is available in multiple forms:

  • Email Support: Write to support@buzzjuice.net for technical or subscription-related issues.
  • Buzzjuice Support Groups: Join the Buzzjuice Help & Support group for community-based assistance.
  • Support FAQs & Knowledgebase: Check the “Support FAQ” forum in the community forums for quick answers.
  • Course Instructor/Facilitator: For lesson-specific clarifications, use the course discussion forum.
  • Buzzjuice Announcements: To get up to date platform activities

💡 Tip: Always check your subscription status first if you cannot access content. Many issues are solved by renewing or updating your subscription.

Learner Activity:

  • Bookmark the Support FAQ and Buzzjuice Announcements links it in your browser. Support links have been placed in the menus and dashboard for easier access.

item.title: Certificates & Badges
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
When you complete the Registration & Orientation quiz with a passing score (60% or above), the system will automatically reward you:

  • Student Badge (under construction) — A Buzzjuice badge displayed on your profile to show your verified readiness.
  • Course Access — Access to the Health & Safety and Elective courses with exclusive lessons and quizzes (provided your subscription is active).

💡 Important: Badges only remain valid while your subscription is active and your orientation has not expired (12-month limit).

Learner Activity:

  • After completing the Registration & Orientation assessment, visit your Buzzjuice Courses to access any Health & Safety course.

item.title: Understanding Expiry & Renewal
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
Your Registration & Orientation status is valid for 12 months. After this period:

  • Your Registration & Orientation (R&O) badge will expire.
  • All related R&O course statistics will be deleted.
  • You must renew your subscription (if expired) and re-complete orientation to regain access.

To help you stay on track, Buzzjuice sends reminder emails at 30, 14, 7, 3, and 1 days before expiry.

💡 Tip: Mark these reminder emails so they don’t end up in your spam folder.

Learner Activity:

  • Add the expiry date of your current orientation to your personal calendar (12 months from completion).

item.title: Next Steps: Beginning Your Health & Safety Journey
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
After completing this orientation and passing the final assessment, you are ready to start the Health & Safety Diploma Program.

Your next steps:

  1. Access Your First Course
    • Go to HS1000 – Fundamentals of Health & Safety.
    • Review the course syllabus and begin Lesson 1.
  2. Check Course Rules
    • Some content remains locked until specific assessments are passed — you must demonstrate competency to continue.
  3. Stay Engaged
    • Participate in discussion forums.
    • Keep your Buzzjuice profile updated (especially contact details).
    • Network with fellow learners through clubs and groups.

💡 Tip: Treat this program like a professional course — set study times, use the timetable template provided in orientation, and engage actively with resources.

Learner Activity:

  • After completing the Registration & Orientation assessment, open HS1000 from your course dashboard and preview the first lesson.

item.title: Support, Certificates & Next Steps - Lesson Wrap-Up
item.dc:creator: drenkaby
item.content:encoded:
You now know:

  • How to get help when you encounter challenges.
  • How your badge (in development) and orientation completion unlock your learning journey.
  • The importance of monitoring expiry and renewal.
  • What to do next — starting HS1000.

Once you finish this lesson, you’ll be ready for the Final Registration & Orientation Assessment.
